awd_titl_txt: Intragrain Oxygen-isotope Zoning and the Fast Grain Boundary Model: A New Approach to Thermal Histories and Fluid-rock Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Minerals are powerful, but tiny, time capsules of past Earth events and conditions. Unpacking these geochemical time capsules involves two major challenges: 1) precise and accurate measurement of mineral composition at the scale of micrometers, and 2) linking micro scale mineral composition to tectonic-scale geologic events. This research project will use recent advances in analytical technology to investigate oxygen isotopes in individual minerals from a tectonically unique region of the western United States. Measured oxygen isotope patterns will be used to quantify temperature, time, and water composition during tectonic deformation. Oxygen isotope data will thus provide new, highly detailed information about the past movement of heat and fluids, which is necessary to understanding ore formation and deformation of Earth's crust. This research will expand geochemical methodologies, both analytical and computational, for transforming small-scale data from minerals into understanding of big-picture geologic events and processes. This award is co-funded by the Petrology & Geochemistry program and EPSCoR (Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research) and will help enable the research training of two undergraduate and two graduate students at the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology. Specifically, advanced students will undertake a project that combines skills in analytical geochemistry and computational modeling that will prepare them for careers that require technological fluency and the ability to perform quantitative data analysis. The proposed project will also help to establish the research program of an early-career female geoscientist.

The spatial variability (zoning) of oxygen-isotope composition within individual mineral grains is, as yet, a largely untapped record of past thermal events and fluid-rock interactions. Many zoning studies have investigated chemical zoning in minerals, but only recently have advances in analytical techniques opened up investigation of isotopic zoning. Oxygen-isotope zoning is particularly useful as a monitor of changing metamorphic conditions and/or fluid-rock interactions over time because the oxygen-isotope composition of minerals is sensitive to temperature and fluid isotopic composition. The Fast Grain Boundary (FGB) conceptual and numerical model aid in linking grain-scale mass transfer to rock microstructure and macrostructure, and then to larger-scale tectonic drivers of mass transfer. Thus, FGB and oxygen-isotope zoning measurements together represent a new approach for developing meaningful, data-constrained interpretations of intragrain compositional heterogeneity. This research will therefore leverage state-of-the-art in situ measurement techniques, in combination with FGB computational tools, to investigate the thermal and fluid histories of several western US metamorphic core complexes as preserved in oxygen-isotope zoning.

por.por_cntn:
Metamorphic core complexes are mountains formed when continents stretch and extend. They are of interest to geologists because records of tectonic extension (versus tectonic collision) are relatively rare and because they can host economic mineral deposits. This project developed an existing tool - measurement of oxygen isotopes - in new ways in order to study the tectonic history of metamorphic core complexes.  

Our team first developed a software modeling tool (Fig. 1), called Fast Grain Boundary or FGB, that uses oxygen isotope data to investigate changes in rock temperature over time. Rock temperature can be a good indicator of rock depth, and changing temperatures can track the upward or downward movement of rocks associated with tectonic activity. For example, data analyzed in this project showed that rocks of the Adirondack Mountains cooled rapidly from 700 ?C to 500 ?C in about 5 million years, likely as a result of rapid upward rock movement. FGB software is useful both for making predictions about oxygen isotope patterns that might be preserved in rocks and for reconstructing rock temperature histories from measured oxygen isotopes (Fig. 1).

We next measured oxygen isotopes in minerals from two metamorphic core complexes and compared them with FGB modeling predictions. The oxygen isotope patterns inside the crystals contain information about cooling and water flow associated with faults (Fig. 2). Minerals in both core complexes commonly preserve low oxygen isotope values, showing that rainwater falling at the surface traveled deep into the Earth's crust along faults during extension and mountain formation (Figs. 3 and 4). Rainwater may have made faulting easier and enhanced mountain formation.

This project provided training for students and early-career scientists through hands-on research. It supported the work of Gabriel Kropf, a Masters student in applied mathematics and statistics, Claudia Roig, a PhD student in geochemistry, and two postdoctoral researchers, Drs.Guillaume Siron and Adrian Castro. Our research team has shared its results is a variety of ways. The Fast Grain Boundary modeling software is freely available for use by other researchers via GitHub. Modeling and geologic results have been presented in a thesis, a scientific journal publication, at four different major scientific conferences, and in several scientific seminars. Additional results from the project will be released in upcoming journal publications.
